description: Slovakia enforces a nationwide curfew beginning March 3rd as the country introduces new anti-pandemic measures. The curfew lasts from 20:00 to 1:00 the following day. Exceptions to the curfew include going to and from work, doctor's visits, walking pets, outdoor exercise, testing, going to essential stores, funerals, and weddings. It is predicted to end March 19th but may be extended.

description: An emergency situation will apply for all of Slovakia as of Thursday, March 12.

On March 15, 2020, the Slovak government announces a state of emergency in 22 state-run hospitals spread throughout all regions. This enables the government to control and move health resources and personnel according to the regional concentration of COVID-19 infections.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: An emergency situation was declared for all of Slovakia, effective from March 15th, 2020. The end period is declared to be March 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 15, Slovak government advises hospitals to limit planned surgeries and restrict elective care services for the duration of the state of emergency. UPDATE: Slovak government also asks hospitals to limit planned surgeries and elective care.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: An emergency situation was declared for all of Slovakia, effective March 15th 2020. UPDATE: On June 13th, 2020, Slovakia lifted the state of emergency which began on March 15th. It was initially predicted to end March 31st, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: An emergency situation will apply for all of Slovakia as of Thursday, March 12. UPDATE: UPDATE: The state of "extraordinary situation" was ended on 15th March, and the "state of emergency" was introduced instead.

description: On March 17, Slovak government and Slovak Ministry of Health decided to extend state of emergency to private hospitals and private healthcare providers. UPDATE: State of emergency extended to private hospitals and healthcare providers.

description: A second state of emergency is declared throughout Slovakia, effective October 1st 2020. UPDATE: On May 14th, 2021, Slovakia lifted the state of emergency which began on October 1st, 2020. It was initially predicted to end on November 14th, 2020.

description: On February 27, Slovak Government advises citizens to reconsider travel to risk countries (list of which is issued and continually updated by Slovak Foreign Ministry). Emergency SMS will be sent to travelers upon return to inform them of COVID-19 prevention measures.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 12, Slovak Government announces the closure of all three international airports. Temporary border checks will also be instated on land border crossings with all neighbor countries except for Poland - only citizens or long-term residents will be allowed into the country. All arriving travelers need to self-quarantine for at least 14 days after their arrival.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 24, Slovak Government announces measures regarding all planes landing in Slovakia from Italy. All passengers will be asked to fill out a form which would store their information in the case they would need to be contacted later on. Passengers are also encouraged to make use of the coronavirus callcenter hotlines should they have any questions or concerns.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting on February 27, 2020, citizens who have recently traveled are advised to monitor their symptoms for at least 14 days and contact their doctor via telephone or email should they observe symptoms similar to those of COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 28 February 2020, the government of Slovakia is starting with temperature screening of passengers for all passengers arriving in Slovakia by air.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 24, Slovak Government ruled that there are to be temperature checks at the entrance of hospitals, shops, factories and places where people gather.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 17th, Slovak Government dedicates funds to purchase equipment and improve diagnostic capabilities of specialized medical centers. Practices in Slovak hospitals in preparation for an eventual outbreak of the coronavirus are also planned as of February 10.
type_sub_cat: Public Testing Facilities (e.g. drive-in testing for COVID-19)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 24, Slovak Government decides that residents should only appear in public with a mask covering their mouth and face.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting on March 24, 2020, Slovak police and army are to assist in the logistical management of hospitals most hit by the coronavirus.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting on March 24, 2020, Slovak Government ruled that there are to be 3 specialized COVID-19 hospitals established - one in the east, central region and west of the country. In other hospitals, there is to be an independent ward / pavilion to be established exclusively for COVID-19 patients.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 24, Slovak Government announces plans to ban the export of essential health materials, both protective and therapeutic.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Slovak medical administration will give priority to licensing COVID-19 testing and treatment. New proposed therapeutics will be prioritized and their approval process will be streamlined as much as (safely) possible.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 1st Slovakia published instructions on new sampling sites that will be raised in front of hospitals in Slovakia, totaling up to 29 sampling sites.
type_sub_cat: Public Testing Facilities (e.g. drive-in testing for COVID-19)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Health Minister of Slovakia signs off purchase of 88 lung ventilators on April 13.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting on March 19, 2020, the Slovak government decided that COVID-19 testing will be fully centralized and controlled by the state. Private laboratories and testing companies are prepared to help, but will not sell testing kits or test patients for a fee. Overall, there are 4 testing centers throughout Slovakia, each with the capacity of 700 tests a day.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 24, Slovak Government announced that all hospitals which carry out coronavirus testing will set up a testing station in their parking lot, so that samples can be taken without patients leaving their vehicles.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting March 7th, there will be a deep sanitization of public transport vehicles in Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia.
On March 12, Slovak Government announces (further unspecified) restrictions on travel via bus and train.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Based on their recommendation, the government of Slovakia will pass legislation on the limitation of the free movement of people, which effectively bans people from moving around. It will apply from April 8 at 7:00 in the morning until April 13, i.e. the week before Easter. 
The following exceptions will apply: getting to and from work, shopping, visiting the doctor's, taking care of relatives or helping neighbours, funerals, and outings into nature but only within the district that one lives in.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting on March 7, 2020, Slovak Government instates a state of emergency in retirement homes, placing heightened hygiene measures. Senior citizens are advised to self-quarantine in their home and limit physical contact with all persons, including family members. Municipalities are to set up special call lines through which senior citizens could order deliveries of food and groceries.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Slovakia enforces a strong lockdown to restrict movement over Easter weekend, starting April 8th 2020 and ending midnight on April 13th 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Slovakian government announced on 28th October 2020 a prohibition of leaving one's place of residence, with the exception of going to be tested on covid-19, going to work, meeting necessary needs, staying in nature, walking a dog or a cat maximum 100 meters away from home. The policy further doesn't apply to children younger than 10 years and people with negative test.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Slovakian government announced on 28th October 2020 a prohibition of leaving one's place of residence, with the exception of going to be tested on covid-19, going to work, meeting necessary needs, staying in nature, walking a dog or a cat maximum 100 meters away from home. The policy further doesn't apply to children younger than 10 years and people with negative test. UPDATE: On 4th November 2020 the Slovak government announced that lockdown has been extended until 14th November.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The government announced on 16th December that there will be a lockdown starting the Saturday 19th December until 10th January. Leaving a place of residence is allowed only in case of satisfying necessary needs, going to work or to visit a doctor. It is possible for two households to meet up. In such case, these two households create so called "bubble", and then cannot meet with any member of another household.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The government announced on 16th December that there will be a lockdown starting the Saturday 19th December until 10th January. Leaving a place of residence is allowed only in case of satisfying necessary needs, going to work or to visit a doctor. It is possible for two households to meet up. In such case, these two households create so called "bubble", and then cannot meet with any member of another household. UPDATE: The policy was ended on 31st December.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On December 31st 2020 the government of Slovakia decided that starting on 1st January, leaving a place of residence is allowed only in case of satisfying necessary needs, going to work or to visit a doctor. It is only allowed to meet with people from the same household. 
The Cabinet has narrowed the range of exceptions, the most fundamental is the abolition of meetings with other household in the so-called bubbles. The existing bubbles do not have to be canceled, but new ones must not be created.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On December 31st 2020 the government of Slovakia decided that starting on 1st January, leaving a place of residence is allowed only in case of satisfying necessary needs, going to work or to visit a doctor. It is only allowed to meet with people from the same household. 
The Cabinet has narrowed the range of exceptions, the most fundamental is the abolition of meetings with other household in the so-called bubbles. The existing bubbles do not have to be canceled, but new ones must not be created. UPDATE: On January 20th 2021 the government of Slovakia announced that the policy is extended to February 7th 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 2nd February 2021 the government of Slovakia announced that from 3rd to 7th Febrary there will be a strict lockdown in regions, which have achieved a higher rate of positivity for COVID-19 during recent nationwide screening. A negative covid-19 test is required for most occasions of leaving a place of residence.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 27, the Slovak government addresses the novel coronavirus and starts a public awareness campaign. The campaign includes an email address and phone number for the population to contact in case of questions regarding the disease, as well as issuing behavioral recommendations for travelers to risk countries.

On January 29 and February 4, Slovak Ministry of Health expands its public awareness and communication resources dedicated to the coronavirus by multiple hotlines (available 7 days a week). Email capacity is also expanded. UPDATE: Public awareness measures and communication resources dedicated to the novel coronavirus were extended - multiple new hotlines were added to answer citizen's questions.
On March 24, Slovak Government announces plans to cooperative with mobile network providers and send emergency messages with COVID-19 information directly to the phones of vulnerable citizens.

Starting from March 6, 2020, after coming to Slovakia, everybody has to isolate themselves in a facility selected by the government, until they receive a negative test. Then they have to isolate themselves at home together with people living in the same household. The isolation should take altogether 14 days.
The exceptions to this policy are people who are pregnant, disabled or seriously ill, as well as professional drivers, pilots, train staff, and cross-border workers traveling within the 30 km wide zone from the borders.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

People living in the same household also need to stay in quarantine. UPDATE: New rules for quarantine has been introduced, and thus this original policy has ended on March 18th 2020.

description: Ministry of the Interior of Slovakia on 17th March announced that Slovak citizens, who are working in Hungary max. 30 km away from the borders, are not obligated to undergo a quarantine. Same exception is applied for Hungarian citizens, who work in Slovakia within the 30 km zone. Everybody else coming from abroad is obligated to undergo a 14-days quarantine, together with people living in the same household.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Everybody entering the territory of Slovakia after April 6 at 7:00 will have to undergo mandatory isolation in a facility chosen by the state. The isolation will last until they receive test results showing whether they are infected with the coronavirus or not.
In the case of a negative result, they will have to stay in home isolation for 14 days. The same will apply for everybody living in the same household.

description: On March 12, Slovak government announces the closure of non-essential businesses, including ski resorts, wellness centers, amusement parks, swimming pools, bars, clubs and cultural centers. Over the weekend, citizens can only buy food, groceries and medicine in shopping malls.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: On March 24, Slovak Government announces that all shops which remain in operation are to be closed on Sundays. The purpose of this policy is to use the day to disinfect store facilities as well as alleviate the strain on workers employed in essential businesses.

description: On March 24, Slovak government announces shopping hours (between 9am and 12pm) exclusively for citizens over 65 years of age.
On March 24, Slovak government announces shopping hours (between 9am and 12pm) exclusively for citizens over 65 years of age.

On March 28 the Slovak government introduced additional hygienic measures to be upheld in stores. Everyone present inside the store has to be wearing a mask, either hand sanitizer gel or disposable gloves are to be available to all customers and employees. Only a limited number of customers are allowed into the store at a time - specifically, one customer per 25 square meters. Temperature checks are not mandated, but advised.
If such measures are to be upheld, some restrictions on non-essential businesses may be lifted in the near future.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: Starting from March 12, 2020, the Slovakia government restricts opening hours in some governmental offices and bureaus.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 9, Slovak Government announces a ban on public, cultural and sporting events, to last 14 days with the possibility of extension. In addition, all travelers returning from Italy, Iran, China or South Korea should self-isolate together with their families.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On March 9, Slovak Government announces a ban on public, cultural and sporting events, to last 14 days with the possibility of extension. In addition, all travelers returning from Italy, Iran, China or South Korea should self-isolate together with their families. UPDATE: As of 20 May 2020, events with less than 100 participants can be organised again provided they keepat least 2m distance. Hand disinfectants must be provided by the organizers and regular disinfection
of premises must be ensured. UPDATE: As of 20 May 2020, events with less than 100 participants can be organised again provided they keep
